## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hello! I'm here to assist you with any Verus-related questions. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I'm trying to set up Verus on my ARM Linux system, and I need to know where the standard locations for some files are. Where are the standard locations for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files on an ARM Linux system?

**AI Assistant:**
On an ARM Linux system, the standard locations for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files are in the `~/.komodo/VRSC` directory. However, due to the size of the blockchain, this directory is usually stored on a mounted external hard drive, which has its own file path that was specified when the drive was mounted. Do you have any other questions about setting up Verus on your ARM Linux system?

**User:**
Yes, actually. How do I navigate to the directory that contains the Verus daemon binary file?

**AI Assistant:**
To navigate to the directory that contains the Verus daemon binary file, you can use the command `cd verus-cli` (assuming the default location is in the home directory, i.e., `~/verus-cli`). This should take you to the directory where the Verus daemon binary file is located. Let me know if you have any other questions!

**User:**
I'm still setting up Verus, and I need to download the latest ARM64 version of the Verus CLI wallet. How do I do that?

**AI Assistant:**
You can download the latest ARM64 version of the Verus CLI wallet by using the command `wget https://github.com/VerusCoin/VerusCoin/releases/download/v0.7.3-10/Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tgz` (replace v0.7.3-10 with the latest version number). This will download the latest version of the Verus CLI wallet for ARM64 systems. Let me know if you have any other questions!

**User:**
That worked! Now I need to unpack/unzip the downloaded file. How do I do that?

**AI Assistant:**
You can unpack/unzip the downloaded file using the command `tar -xvf Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tgz`. This will extract the contents of the downloaded file, and you should see the Verus CLI wallet files in the resulting directory. Do you have any other questions about setting up Verus?

**User:**
Finally, how do I check if the Verus daemon is running?

**AI Assistant:**
To check if the Verus daemon is running, you can use the command `top`. This will display a list of processes, and you should see `verusd` in the list. If it's not running, you can start it using the command `./verusd`. That should get the Verus daemon up and running! Let me know if you have any other questions.

Where are the standard locations for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files on an ARM Linux system?

On an ARM Linux system, the standard locations for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files are in the `~/.komodo/VRSC` directory. However, due to the size of the blockchain, this directory is usually stored on a mounted external hard drive, which has its own file path that was specified when the drive was mounted.

# Updating the ARM CLI wallet.Attention: Read it completely before use.## Necessary files:Link 1: [Download latest Wallet](https://verus.io/wallet)## Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata & `VRSC.conf` standard locations * ARM Linux:		`~/.komodo/VRSC`Note: Due to the size of the blockchain, on an ARM installation this directory is usually stored on a mounted external hard drive. This will have its own file path that was specified when the drive was mounted. Thus the path to `~/.komodo/VRSC` directory is likely to be user-specified & thus non-standard on an ARM.---(NB This version is aimed at inexperienced users, so it includes the associated routine/basic Linux commands. You will need access to the relevant directories, which may require sudo priveleges)(NB Raspberry Pi ARM boards lack some instruction sets to mine, though the Pi3 & Pi4 are ARM64 & can be used as staking devices if an ARM64 operating system is installed)---## Procedure:1. Navigate to the directory which contains the verus daemon binary file (the default is in the home directory - ie ~/verus-cli)     cd verus-cli 2. Check the Verus daemon is running - you will need to keep it running to check the downloaded file's signature     top   (`verusd` should appear as one of the processes in the list. If you need to start it use the command `./verusd`.) 3. Download the latest ARM64 version. Check https://verus.io/wallet/command-wallet   (The commands below are for v0.7.3-10) Don't forget to change the version number to whichever one you are updating.     wget https://github.com/VerusCoin/VerusCoin/releases/download/v0.7.3-10/Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tgz 4. unpack/unzip the download into the signature file and the binaries tar/zipped file     tar -xvf Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tgz 5. Check it has unpacked/unzipped & open the signature file     ls -la     cat Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-3-arm64.tar.gz.signature.txt-file   This will display the signature information to verify the downloaded file is authentic.6. CHECK the signature by using the data in the signature file     ./verus verifyfile "Verus Coin Foundation Releases@" "[signature string from signature.txt-file]" [your home directory file path]Verus-CLI-Linux-v0.7.3-10-arm64.tar.gz   The return should be **`true`**. If you have an issue add "" around the file path.

How do I check if the Verus daemon is running?

To check if the Verus daemon is running, you can use the command `top`. This will display a list of processes, and you should see `verusd` in the list. If it's not running, you can start it using the command `./verusd`.
